text_entry: I do desire we may be better strangers.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I pray you, mar no more trees with writing

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: love-songs in their barks.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I pray you, mar no more of my verses with reading

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: them ill-favouredly.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Rosalind is your love's name?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Yes, just.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I do not like her name.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: There was no thought of pleasing you when she was

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: christened.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: What stature is she of?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Just as high as my heart.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You are full of pretty answers. Have you not been

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: acquainted with goldsmiths' wives, and conned them

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: out of rings?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Not so; but I answer you right painted cloth, from

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: whence you have studied your questions.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: You have a nimble wit: I think 'twas made of

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Atalanta's heels. Will you sit down with me? and

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: we two will rail against our mistress the world and

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: all our misery.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will chide no breather in the world but myself,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: against whom I know most faults.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: The worst fault you have is to be in love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: 'Tis a fault I will not change for your best virtue.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am weary of you.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: By my troth, I was seeking for a fool when I found

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: He is drowned in the brook: look but in, and you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: shall see him.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: There I shall see mine own figure.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Which I take to be either a fool or a cipher.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I'll tarry no longer with you: farewell, good

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Signior Love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am glad of your departure: adieu, good Monsieur

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Melancholy.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exit JAQUES

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: [Aside to CELIA]  I will speak to him, like a saucy

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: lackey and under that habit play the knave with him.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you hear, forester?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Very well: what would you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I pray you, what is't o'clock?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You should ask me what time o' day: there's no clock

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: in the forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then there is no true lover in the forest; else

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sighing every minute and groaning every hour would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: detect the lazy foot of Time as well as a clock.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And why not the swift foot of Time? had not that

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: been as proper?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By no means, sir: Time travels in divers paces with

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: divers persons. I'll tell you who Time ambles

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: withal, who Time trots withal, who Time gallops

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: withal and who he stands still withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, he trots hard with a young maid between the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: contract of her marriage and the day it is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: solemnized: if the interim be but a se'nnight,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Time's pace is so hard that it seems the length of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: seven year.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who ambles Time withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With a priest that lacks Latin and a rich man that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hath not the gout, for the one sleeps easily because

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he cannot study, and the other lives merrily because

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: he feels no pain, the one lacking the burden of lean

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and wasteful learning, the other knowing no burden

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of heavy tedious penury; these Time ambles withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who doth he gallop withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With a thief to the gallows, for though he go as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: softly as foot can fall, he thinks himself too soon there.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who stays it still withal?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With lawyers in the vacation, for they sleep between

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: term and term and then they perceive not how Time moves.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Where dwell you, pretty youth?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: With this shepherdess, my sister; here in the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: skirts of the forest, like fringe upon a petticoat.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Are you native of this place?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Your accent is something finer than you could

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: purchase in so removed a dwelling.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I have been told so of many: but indeed an old

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: religious uncle of mine taught me to speak, who was

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: in his youth an inland man; one that knew courtship

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: too well, for there he fell in love. I have heard

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him read many lectures against it, and I thank God

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I am not a woman, to be touched with so many

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: giddy offences as he hath generally taxed their

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: whole sex withal.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Can you remember any of the principal evils that he

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: laid to the charge of women?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: There were none principal; they were all like one

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: another as half-pence are, every one fault seeming

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: monstrous till his fellow fault came to match it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I prithee, recount some of them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, I will not cast away my physic but on those that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are sick. There is a man haunts the forest, that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: abuses our young plants with carving 'Rosalind' on

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: their barks; hangs odes upon hawthorns and elegies

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: on brambles, all, forsooth, deifying the name of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Rosalind: if I could meet that fancy-monger I would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: give him some good counsel, for he seems to have the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: quotidian of love upon him.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I am he that is so love-shaked: I pray you tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: your remedy.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: There is none of my uncle's marks upon you: he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: taught me how to know a man in love; in which cage

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of rushes I am sure you are not prisoner.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What were his marks?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A lean cheek, which you have not, a blue eye and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sunken, which you have not, an unquestionable

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: spirit, which you have not, a beard neglected,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: which you have not; but I pardon you for that, for

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: simply your having in beard is a younger brother's

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: revenue: then your hose should be ungartered, your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: untied and every thing about you demonstrating a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: careless desolation; but you are no such man; you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are rather point-device in your accoutrements as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: loving yourself than seeming the lover of any other.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Fair youth, I would I could make thee believe I love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Me believe it! you may as soon make her that you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: love believe it; which, I warrant, she is apter to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: do than to confess she does: that is one of the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: points in the which women still give the lie to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: their consciences. But, in good sooth, are you he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that hangs the verses on the trees, wherein Rosalind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: is so admired?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I swear to thee, youth, by the white hand of

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Rosalind, I am that he, that unfortunate he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But are you so much in love as your rhymes speak?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Neither rhyme nor reason can express how much.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Love is merely a madness, and, I tell you, deserves

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as well a dark house and a whip as madmen do: and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the reason why they are not so punished and cured

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: is, that the lunacy is so ordinary that the whippers

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are in love too. Yet I profess curing it by counsel.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Did you ever cure any so?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Yes, one, and in this manner. He was to imagine me

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his love, his mistress; and I set him every day to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: woo me: at which time would I, being but a moonish

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: youth, grieve, be effeminate, changeable, longing

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and liking, proud, fantastical, apish, shallow,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: inconstant, full of tears, full of smiles, for every

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: passion something and for no passion truly any

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thing, as boys and women are for the most part

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cattle of this colour; would now like him, now loathe

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him; then entertain him, then forswear him; now weep

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: for him, then spit at him; that I drave my suitor

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: from his mad humour of love to a living humour of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: madness; which was, to forswear the full stream of

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the world, and to live in a nook merely monastic.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And thus I cured him; and this way will I take upon

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me to wash your liver as clean as a sound sheep's

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: heart, that there shall not be one spot of love in't.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would not be cured, youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would cure you, if you would but call me Rosalind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and come every day to my cote and woo me.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Now, by the faith of my love, I will: tell me

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: where it is.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Go with me to it and I'll show it you and by the way

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you shall tell me where in the forest you live.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will you go?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With all my heart, good youth.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay you must call me Rosalind. Come, sister, will you go?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE III. The forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY; JAQUES behind

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Come apace, good Audrey: I will fetch up your

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: goats, Audrey. And how, Audrey? am I the man yet?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: doth my simple feature content you?

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Your features! Lord warrant us! what features!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I am here with thee and thy goats, as the most

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: capricious poet, honest Ovid, was among the Goths.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Aside]  O knowledge ill-inhabited, worse than Jove

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: in a thatched house!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: When a man's verses cannot be understood, nor a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: man's good wit seconded with the forward child

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Understanding, it strikes a man more dead than a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: great reckoning in a little room. Truly, I would

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the gods had made thee poetical.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: I do not know what 'poetical' is: is it honest in

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: deed and word? is it a true thing?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: No, truly; for the truest poetry is the most

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: feigning; and lovers are given to poetry, and what

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Do you wish then that the gods had made me poetical?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I do, truly; for thou swearest to me thou art

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: honest: now, if thou wert a poet, I might have some

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: hope thou didst feign.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Would you not have me honest?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: No, truly, unless thou wert hard-favoured; for

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: honesty coupled to beauty is to have honey a sauce to sugar.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Aside]  A material fool!

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Well, I am not fair; and therefore I pray the gods

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: make me honest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, and to cast away honesty upon a foul slut

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: were to put good meat into an unclean dish.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Well, praised be the gods for thy foulness!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sluttishness may come hereafter. But be it as it may

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: be, I will marry thee, and to that end I have been

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with Sir Oliver Martext, the vicar of the next

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: village, who hath promised to meet me in this place

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: of the forest and to couple us.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Aside]  I would fain see this meeting.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Well, the gods give us joy!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Amen. A man may, if he were of a fearful heart,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: stagger in this attempt; for here we have no temple

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: but the wood, no assembly but horn-beasts. But what

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: though? C ourage! As horns are odious, they are

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: necessary. It is said, 'many a man knows no end of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: his goods:' right; many a man has good horns, and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: knows no end of them. Well, that is the dowry of

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: his wife; 'tis none of his own getting. Horns?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Even so. Poor men alone? No, no; the noblest deer

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: hath them as huge as the rascal. Is the single man

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: therefore blessed? No: as a walled town is more

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: worthier than a village, so is the forehead of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: married man more honourable than the bare brow of a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: bachelor; and by how much defence is better than no

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: skill, by so much is a horn more precious than to

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: want. Here comes Sir Oliver.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter SIR OLIVER MARTEXT

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Sir Oliver Martext, you are well met: will you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: dispatch us here under this tree, or shall we go

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with you to your chapel?

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Is there none here to give the woman?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I will not take her on gift of any man.

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Truly, she must be given, or the marriage is not lawful.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: [Advancing]

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Proceed, proceed I'll give her.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Good even, good Master What-ye-call't: how do you,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: sir? You are very well met: God 'ild you for your

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: last company: I am very glad to see you: even a

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: toy in hand here, sir: nay, pray be covered.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Will you be married, motley?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: As the ox hath his bow, sir, the horse his curb and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the falcon her bells, so man hath his desires; and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: as pigeons bill, so wedlock would be nibbling.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: married under a bush like a beggar? Get you to

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: church, and have a good priest that can tell you

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: what marriage is: this fellow will but join you

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: together as they join wainscot; then one of you will

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: [Aside]  I am not in the mind but I were better to be

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: married of him than of another: for he is not like

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: to marry me well; and not being well married, it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: will be a good excuse for me hereafter to leave my wife.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Go thou with me, and let me counsel thee.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: 'Come, sweet Audrey:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: We must be married, or we must live in bawdry.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Farewell, good Master Oliver: not,--

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: O sweet Oliver,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: O brave Oliver,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Leave me not behind thee: but,--

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Wind away,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Begone, I say,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: I will not to wedding with thee.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt JAQUES, TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: 'Tis no matter: ne'er a fantastical knave of them

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: all shall flout me out of my calling.

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: SCENE IV. The forest.

speaker: SIR OLIVER MARTEXT
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Never talk to me; I will weep.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Do, I prithee; but yet have the grace to consider

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: that tears do not become a man.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But have I not cause to weep?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: As good cause as one would desire; therefore weep.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: His very hair is of the dissembling colour.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Something browner than Judas's marry, his kisses are

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Judas's own children.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I' faith, his hair is of a good colour.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: An excellent colour: your chestnut was ever the only colour.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And his kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of holy bread.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: He hath bought a pair of cast lips of Diana: a nun

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: of winter's sisterhood kisses not more religiously;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: the very ice of chastity is in them.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But why did he swear he would come this morning, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: comes not?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Nay, certainly, there is no truth in him.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you think so?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Yes; I think he is not a pick-purse nor a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: horse-stealer, but for his verity in love, I do

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: think him as concave as a covered goblet or a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: worm-eaten nut.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Not true in love?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Yes, when he is in; but I think he is not in.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You have heard him swear downright he was.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: 'Was' is not 'is:' besides, the oath of a lover is

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: no stronger than the word of a tapster; they are

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: both the confirmer of false reckonings. He attends

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: here in the forest on the duke your father.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I met the duke yesterday and had much question with

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him: he asked me of what parentage I was; I told

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him, of as good as he; so he laughed and let me go.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But what talk we of fathers, when there is such a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: man as Orlando?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O, that's a brave man! he writes brave verses,

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: speaks brave words, swears brave oaths and breaks

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: them bravely, quite traverse, athwart the heart of

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: his lover; as a puisny tilter, that spurs his horse

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: but on one side, breaks his staff like a noble

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: goose: but all's brave that youth mounts and folly

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: guides. Who comes here?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter CORIN

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Mistress and master, you have oft inquired

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: After the shepherd that complain'd of love,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Who you saw sitting by me on the turf,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Praising the proud disdainful shepherdess

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: That was his mistress.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Well, and what of him?

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: If you will see a pageant truly play'd,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Between the pale complexion of true love

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: And the red glow of scorn and proud disdain,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Go hence a little and I shall conduct you,

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: If you will mark it.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, come, let us remove:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: The sight of lovers feedeth those in love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Bring us to this sight, and you shall say

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I'll prove a busy actor in their play.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sweet Phebe, do not scorn me; do not, Phebe;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Say that you love me not, but say not so

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: In bitterness. The common executioner,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Whose heart the accustom'd sight of death makes hard,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Falls not the axe upon the humbled neck

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: But first begs pardon: will you sterner be

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Than he that dies and lives by bloody drops?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and CORIN, behind

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I would not be thy executioner:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I fly thee, for I would not injure thee.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thou tell'st me there is murder in mine eye:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: 'Tis pretty, sure, and very probable,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: That eyes, that are the frail'st and softest things,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Who shut their coward gates on atomies,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Should be call'd tyrants, butchers, murderers!

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Now I do frown on thee with all my heart;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And if mine eyes can wound, now let them kill thee:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Now counterfeit to swoon; why now fall down;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Or if thou canst not, O, for shame, for shame,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Lie not, to say mine eyes are murderers!

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Now show the wound mine eye hath made in thee:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Scratch thee but with a pin, and there remains

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Some scar of it; lean but upon a rush,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: The cicatrice and capable impressure

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thy palm some moment keeps; but now mine eyes,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Which I have darted at thee, hurt thee not,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Nor, I am sure, there is no force in eyes

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: That can do hurt.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: O dear Phebe,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If ever,--as that ever may be near,--

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: You meet in some fresh cheek the power of fancy,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Then shall you know the wounds invisible

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That love's keen arrows make.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But till that time

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Come not thou near me: and when that time comes,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Afflict me with thy mocks, pity me not;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: As till that time I shall not pity thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And why, I pray you? Who might be your mother,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That you insult, exult, and all at once,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Over the wretched? What though you have no beauty,--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As, by my faith, I see no more in you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than without candle may go dark to bed--

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Must you be therefore proud and pitiless?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, what means this? Why do you look on me?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I see no more in you than in the ordinary

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Of nature's sale-work. 'Od's my little life,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I think she means to tangle my eyes too!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, faith, proud mistress, hope not after it:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: 'Tis not your inky brows, your black silk hair,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Your bugle eyeballs, nor your cheek of cream,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That can entame my spirits to your worship.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You foolish shepherd, wherefore do you follow her,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Like foggy south puffing with wind and rain?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You are a thousand times a properer man

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than she a woman: 'tis such fools as you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That makes the world full of ill-favour'd children:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: 'Tis not her glass, but you, that flatters her;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And out of you she sees herself more proper

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than any of her lineaments can show her.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, mistress, know yourself: down on your knees,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And thank heaven, fasting, for a good man's love:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: For I must tell you friendly in your ear,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Sell when you can: you are not for all markets:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Cry the man mercy; love him; take his offer:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Foul is most foul, being foul to be a scoffer.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: So take her to thee, shepherd: fare you well.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Sweet youth, I pray you, chide a year together:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I had rather hear you chide than this man woo.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: He's fallen in love with your foulness and she'll

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: fall in love with my anger. If it be so, as fast as

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: she answers thee with frowning looks, I'll sauce her

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with bitter words. Why look you so upon me?

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: For no ill will I bear you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I pray you, do not fall in love with me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: For I am falser than vows made in wine:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Besides, I like you not. If you will know my house,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: 'Tis at the tuft of olives here hard by.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will you go, sister? Shepherd, ply her hard.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, sister. Shepherdess, look on him better,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And be not proud: though all the world could see,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: None could be so abused in sight as he.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, to our flock.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt ROSALIND, CELIA and CORIN

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Dead Shepherd, now I find thy saw of might,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: 'Who ever loved that loved not at first sight?'

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sweet Phebe,--

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Ha, what say'st thou, Silvius?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sweet Phebe, pity me.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Wherever sorrow is, relief would be:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If you do sorrow at my grief in love,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: By giving love your sorrow and my grief

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Were both extermined.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thou hast my love: is not that neighbourly?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I would have you.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Why, that were covetousness.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Silvius, the time was that I hated thee,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And yet it is not that I bear thee love;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But since that thou canst talk of love so well,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Thy company, which erst was irksome to me,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I will endure, and I'll employ thee too:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But do not look for further recompense

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Than thine own gladness that thou art employ'd.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: So holy and so perfect is my love,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And I in such a poverty of grace,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That I shall think it a most plenteous crop

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: To glean the broken ears after the man

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That the main harvest reaps: loose now and then

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: A scatter'd smile, and that I'll live upon.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Know'st now the youth that spoke to me erewhile?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Not very well, but I have met him oft;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: That the old carlot once was master of.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Think not I love him, though I ask for him:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: 'Tis but a peevish boy; yet he talks well;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But what care I for words? yet words do well

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: It is a pretty youth: not very pretty:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But, sure, he's proud, and yet his pride becomes him:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: He'll make a proper man: the best thing in him

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Is his complexion; and faster than his tongue

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Did make offence his eye did heal it up.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: He is not very tall; yet for his years he's tall:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: His leg is but so so; and yet 'tis well:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: There was a pretty redness in his lip,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: A little riper and more lusty red

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Than that mix'd in his cheek; 'twas just the difference

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Between the constant red and mingled damask.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: There be some women, Silvius, had they mark'd him

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: In parcels as I did, would have gone near

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: To fall in love with him; but, for my part,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I love him not nor hate him not; and yet

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I have more cause to hate him than to love him:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: For what had he to do to chide at me?

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: He said mine eyes were black and my hair black:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And, now I am remember'd, scorn'd at me:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I marvel why I answer'd not again:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: But that's all one; omittance is no quittance.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I'll write to him a very taunting letter,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And thou shalt bear it: wilt thou, Silvius?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Phebe, with all my heart.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I'll write it straight;

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: The matter's in my head and in my heart:

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: I will be bitter with him and passing short.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Go with me, Silvius.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: SCENE I. The forest.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND, CELIA, and JAQUES

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I prithee, pretty youth, let me be better acquainted

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: with thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: They say you are a melancholy fellow.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I am so; I do love it better than laughing.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Those that are in extremity of either are abominable

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: fellows and betray themselves to every modern

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: censure worse than drunkards.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Why, 'tis good to be sad and say nothing.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why then, 'tis good to be a post.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: I have neither the scholar's melancholy, which is

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: emulation, nor the musician's, which is fantastical,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: nor the courtier's, which is proud, nor the

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: soldier's, which is ambitious, nor the lawyer's,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: which is politic, nor the lady's, which is nice, nor

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: the lover's, which is all these: but it is a

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: melancholy of mine own, compounded of many simples,

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: extracted from many objects, and indeed the sundry's

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: contemplation of my travels, in which my often

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: rumination wraps me m a most humorous sadness.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A traveller! By my faith, you have great reason to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: be sad: I fear you have sold your own lands to see

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: other men's; then, to have seen much and to have

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: nothing, is to have rich eyes and poor hands.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Yes, I have gained my experience.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And your experience makes you sad: I had rather have

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: a fool to make me merry than experience to make me

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sad; and to travel for it too!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Good day and happiness, dear Rosalind!

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Nay, then, God be wi' you, an you talk in blank verse.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Farewell, Monsieur Traveller: look you lisp and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wear strange suits, disable all the benefits of your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: own country, be out of love with your nativity and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: almost chide God for making you that countenance you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: are, or I will scarce think you have swam in a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: gondola. Why, how now, Orlando! where have you been

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: all this while? You a lover! An you serve me such

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: another trick, never come in my sight more.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Break an hour's promise in love! He that will

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: divide a minute into a thousand parts and break but

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: a part of the thousandth part of a minute in the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: affairs of love, it may be said of him that Cupid

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hath clapped him o' the shoulder, but I'll warrant

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: him heart-whole.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Pardon me, dear Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight: I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: had as lief be wooed of a snail.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Of a snail?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: carries his house on his head; a better jointure,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I think, than you make a woman: besides he brings

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his destiny with him.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What's that?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: beholding to your wives for: but he comes armed in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: his fortune and prevents the slander of his wife.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And I am your Rosalind.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Rosalind of a better leer than you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, woo me, woo me, for now I am in a holiday

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: humour and like enough to consent. What would you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: say to me now, an I were your very very Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would kiss before I spoke.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, you were better speak first, and when you were

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: gravelled for lack of matter, you might take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: occasion to kiss. Very good orators, when they are

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: out, they will spit; and for lovers lacking--God

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: warn us!--matter, the cleanliest shift is to kiss.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: How if the kiss be denied?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new matter.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress, or

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What, of my suit?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Am not I your Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I take some joy to say you are, because I would be

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: talking of her.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well in her person I say I will not have you.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Then in mine own person I die.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: almost six thousand years old, and in all this time

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: there was not any man died in his own person,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: videlicit, in a love-cause. Troilus had his brains

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: dashed out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: could to die before, and he is one of the patterns

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of love. Leander, he would have lived many a fair

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: year, though Hero had turned nun, if it had not been

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: for a hot midsummer night; for, good youth, he went

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: but forth to wash him in the Hellespont and being

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: taken with the cramp was drowned and the foolish

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: coroners of that age found it was 'Hero of Sestos.'

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But these are all lies: men have died from time to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: time and worms have eaten them, but not for love.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind,

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: for, I protest, her frown might kill me.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come, now

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: disposition, and ask me what you will. I will grant

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: it.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Then love me, Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays and all.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And wilt thou have me?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, and twenty such.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: What sayest thou?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Are you not good?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I hope so.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, sister, you shall be the priest and marry us.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Give me your hand, Orlando. What do you say, sister?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Pray thee, marry us.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I cannot say the words.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You must begin, 'Will you, Orlando--'

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Go to. Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I will.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, but when?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Why now; as fast as she can marry us.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Then you must say 'I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.'

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I might ask you for your commission; but I do take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thee, Orlando, for my husband: there's a girl goes

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: before the priest; and certainly a woman's thought

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: runs before her actions.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: So do all thoughts; they are winged.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Now tell me how long you would have her after you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: have possessed her.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: For ever and a day.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Say 'a day,' without the 'ever.' No, no, Orlando;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: men are April when they woo, December when they wed:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: maids are May when they are maids, but the sky

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: changes when they are wives. I will be more jealous

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: new-fangled than an ape, more giddy in my desires

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: than a monkey: I will weep for nothing, like Diana

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: in the fountain, and I will do that when you are

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: disposed to be merry; I will laugh like a hyen, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that when thou art inclined to sleep.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: But will my Rosalind do so?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By my life, she will do as I do.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: O, but she is wise.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or else she could not have the wit to do this: the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wiser, the waywarder: make the doors upon a woman's

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wit and it will out at the casement; shut that and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: 'twill out at the key-hole; stop that, 'twill fly

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: with the smoke out at the chimney.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: 'Wit, whither wilt?'

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Nay, you might keep that cheque for it till you met

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: your wife's wit going to your neighbour's bed.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And what wit could wit have to excuse that?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: never take her without her answer, unless you take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: her without her tongue. O, that woman that cannot

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: make her fault her husband's occasion, let her

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: never nurse her child herself, for she will breed

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: it like a fool!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alas! dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I must attend the duke at dinner: by two o'clock I

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: will be with thee again.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Ay, go your ways, go your ways; I knew what you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: would prove: my friends told me as much, and I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thought no less: that flattering tongue of yours

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: won me: 'tis but one cast away, and so, come,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: death! Two o'clock is your hour?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ay, sweet Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: me, and by all pretty oaths that are not dangerous,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: if you break one jot of your promise or come one

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: minute behind your hour, I will think you the most

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: pathetical break-promise and the most hollow lover

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind that

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: may be chosen out of the gross band of the

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: unfaithful: therefore beware my censure and keep

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: your promise.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Rosalind: so adieu.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: offenders, and let Time try: adieu.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exit ORLANDO

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: You have simply misused our sex in your love-prate:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: we must have your doublet and hose plucked over your

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: head, and show the world what the bird hath done to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: her own nest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: didst know how many fathom deep I am in love! But

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: it cannot be sounded: my affection hath an unknown

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: bottom, like the bay of Portugal.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Or rather, bottomless, that as fast as you pour

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: affection in, it runs out.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of thought, conceived of spleen and born of madness,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that blind rascally boy that abuses every one's eyes

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: am in love. I'll tell thee, Aliena, I cannot be out

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of the sight of Orlando: I'll go find a shadow and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sigh till he come.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And I'll sleep.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: SCENE II. The forest.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter JAQUES, Lords, and Foresters

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Which is he that killed the deer?

speaker: A Lord
text_entry: Sir, it was I.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Let's present him to the duke, like a Roman

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: conqueror; and it would do well to set the deer's

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: horns upon his head, for a branch of victory. Have

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: you no song, forester, for this purpose?

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Yes, sir.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: Sing it: 'tis no matter how it be in tune, so it

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: make noise enough.

speaker: JAQUES
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: What shall he have that kill'd the deer?

speaker: Forester
text_entry: His leather skin and horns to wear.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Then sing him home;

speaker: Forester
text_entry: The rest shall bear this burden

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Take thou no scorn to wear the horn;

speaker: Forester
text_entry: It was a crest ere thou wast born:

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Thy father's father wore it,

speaker: Forester
text_entry: And thy father bore it:

speaker: Forester
text_entry: The horn, the horn, the lusty horn

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Is not a thing to laugh to scorn.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Forester
text_entry: SCENE III. The forest.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND and CELIA

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: How say you now? Is it not past two o'clock? and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: here much Orlando!

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain, he

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: hath ta'en his bow and arrows and is gone forth to

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: sleep. Look, who comes here.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Enter SILVIUS

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: My errand is to you, fair youth;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: My gentle Phebe bid me give you this:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I know not the contents; but, as I guess

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: By the stern brow and waspish action

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Which she did use as she was writing of it,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It bears an angry tenor: pardon me:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I am but as a guiltless messenger.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Patience herself would startle at this letter

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And play the swaggerer; bear this, bear all:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She calls me proud, and that she could not love me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Were man as rare as phoenix. 'Od's my will!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Her love is not the hare that I do hunt:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: This is a letter of your own device.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: No, I protest, I know not the contents:

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Phebe did write it.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Come, come, you are a fool

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And turn'd into the extremity of love.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I saw her hand: she has a leathern hand.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A freestone-colour'd hand; I verily did think

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That her old gloves were on, but 'twas her hands:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She has a huswife's hand; but that's no matter:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I say she never did invent this letter;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: This is a man's invention and his hand.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Sure, it is hers.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, 'tis a boisterous and a cruel style.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: A style for-challengers; why, she defies me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Like Turk to Christian: women's gentle brain

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Such Ethiope words, blacker in their effect

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: So please you, for I never heard it yet;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Yet heard too much of Phebe's cruelty.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Reads

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Art thou god to shepherd turn'd,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That a maiden's heart hath burn'd?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Can a woman rail thus?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Call you this railing?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: [Reads]

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why, thy godhead laid apart,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Warr'st thou with a woman's heart?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Did you ever hear such railing?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whiles the eye of man did woo me,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: That could do no vengeance to me.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Meaning me a beast.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: If the scorn of your bright eyne

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Have power to raise such love in mine,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Alack, in me what strange effect

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Would they work in mild aspect!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whiles you chid me, I did love;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: How then might your prayers move!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: He that brings this love to thee

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Little knows this love in me:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And by him seal up thy mind;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Whether that thy youth and kind

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Will the faithful offer take

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Of me and all that I can make;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Or else by him my love deny,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And then I'll study how to die.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: Call you this chiding?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Alas, poor shepherd!

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Do you pity him? no, he deserves no pity. Wilt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thou love such a woman? What, to make thee an

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: instrument and play false strains upon thee! not to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: be endured! Well, go your way to her, for I see

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: love hath made thee a tame snake, and say this to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: her: that if she love me, I charge her to love

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thee; if she will not, I will never have her unless

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: thou entreat for her. If you be a true lover,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: hence, and not a word; for here comes more company.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exit SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter OLIVER

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Good morrow, fair ones: pray you, if you know,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Where in the purlieus of this forest stands

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A sheep-cote fenced about with olive trees?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: West of this place, down in the neighbour bottom:

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Left on your right hand brings you to the place.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: But at this hour the house doth keep itself;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: There's none within.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: If that an eye may profit by a tongue,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Then should I know you by description;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Such garments and such years: 'The boy is fair,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Of female favour, and bestows himself

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Like a ripe sister: the woman low

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And browner than her brother.' Are not you

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The owner of the house I did inquire for?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: It is no boast, being ask'd, to say we are.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Orlando doth commend him to you both,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And to that youth he calls his Rosalind

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I am: what must we understand by this?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Some of my shame; if you will know of me

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: What man I am, and how, and why, and where

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: This handkercher was stain'd.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray you, tell it.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: When last the young Orlando parted from you

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: He left a promise to return again

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Within an hour, and pacing through the forest,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Lo, what befell! he threw his eye aside,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And mark what object did present itself:

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Under an oak, whose boughs were moss'd with age

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And high top bald with dry antiquity,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A wretched ragged man, o'ergrown with hair,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Lay sleeping on his back: about his neck

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A green and gilded snake had wreathed itself,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who with her head nimble in threats approach'd

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The opening of his mouth; but suddenly,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Seeing Orlando, it unlink'd itself,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And with indented glides did slip away

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Into a bush: under which bush's shade

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: When that the sleeping man should stir; for 'tis

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The royal disposition of that beast

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead:

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: This seen, Orlando did approach the man

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And found it was his brother, his elder brother.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: O, I have heard him speak of that same brother;

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: And he did render him the most unnatural

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: That lived amongst men.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And well he might so do,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: For well I know he was unnatural.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, to Orlando: did he leave him there,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Food to the suck'd and hungry lioness?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Twice did he turn his back and purposed so;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And nature, stronger than his just occasion,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Made him give battle to the lioness,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who quickly fell before him: in which hurtling

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: From miserable slumber I awaked.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Are you his brother?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Wast you he rescued?

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Was't you that did so oft contrive to kill him?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: 'Twas I; but 'tis not I I do not shame

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: To tell you what I was, since my conversion

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: But, for the bloody napkin?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: By and by.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: When from the first to last betwixt us two

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Tears our recountments had most kindly bathed,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: As how I came into that desert place:--

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: In brief, he led me to the gentle duke,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Committing me unto my brother's love;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Who led me instantly unto his cave,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: There stripp'd himself, and here upon his arm

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: The lioness had torn some flesh away,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And cried, in fainting, upon Rosalind.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Brief, I recover'd him, bound up his wound;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And, after some small space, being strong at heart,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: He sent me hither, stranger as I am,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: To tell this story, that you might excuse

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: His broken promise, and to give this napkin

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Dyed in his blood unto the shepherd youth

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: That he in sport doth call his Rosalind.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: ROSALIND swoons

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Why, how now, Ganymede! sweet Ganymede!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Many will swoon when they do look on blood.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Look, he recovers.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would I were at home.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: We'll lead you thither.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: I pray you, will you take him by the arm?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Be of good cheer, youth: you a man! you lack a

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: man's heart.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: think this was well counterfeited! I pray you, tell

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: your brother how well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho!

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: This was not counterfeit: there is too great

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: testimony in your complexion that it was a passion

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: of earnest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Counterfeit, I assure you.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: So I do: but, i' faith, I should have been a woman by right.

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: Come, you look paler and paler: pray you, draw

speaker: CELIA
text_entry: homewards. Good sir, go with us.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: That will I, for I must bear answer back

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: How you excuse my brother, Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I shall devise something: but, I pray you, commend

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: my counterfeiting to him. Will you go?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: SCENE I. The forest.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: We shall find a time, Audrey; patience, gentle Audrey.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: gentleman's saying.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Martext. But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: forest lays claim to you.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Ay, I know who 'tis; he hath no interest in me in

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: the world: here comes the man you mean.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown: by my

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: troth, we that have good wits have much to answer

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: for; we shall be flouting; we cannot hold.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter WILLIAM

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Good even, Audrey.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: God ye good even, William.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: And good even to you, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Good even, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: head; nay, prithee, be covered. How old are you, friend?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Five and twenty, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A ripe age. Is thy name William?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: William, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: A fair name. Wast born i' the forest here?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Ay, sir, I thank God.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: 'Thank God;' a good answer. Art rich?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Faith, sir, so so.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: 'So so' is good, very good, very excellent good; and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: yet it is not; it is but so so. Art thou wise?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Why, thou sayest well. I do now remember a saying,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: 'The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: knows himself to be a fool.' The heathen

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a grape,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: would open his lips when he put it into his mouth;

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: meaning thereby that grapes were made to eat and

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: lips to open. You do love this maid?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: I do, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Give me your hand. Art thou learned?

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: No, sir.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Then learn this of me: to have, is to have; for it

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is a figure in rhetoric that drink, being poured out

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: of a cup into a glass, by filling the one doth empty

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: the other; for all your writers do consent that ipse

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: is he: now, you are not ipse, for I am he.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Which he, sir?

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore, you

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: clown, abandon,--which is in the vulgar leave,--the

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: society,--which in the boorish is company,--of this

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: female,--which in the common is woman; which

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: together is, abandon the society of this female, or,

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: understanding, diest; or, to wit I kill thee, make

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: thee away, translate thy life into death, thy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: liberty into bondage: I will deal in poison with

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: thee, or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: with thee in faction; I will o'errun thee with

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: policy; I will kill thee a hundred and fifty ways:

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: therefore tremble and depart.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Do, good William.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: God rest you merry, sir.

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: WILLIAM
text_entry: Enter CORIN

speaker: CORIN
text_entry: Our master and mistress seeks you; come, away, away!

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Trip, Audrey! trip, Audrey! I attend, I attend.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: SCENE II. The forest.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Enter ORLANDO and OLIVER

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Is't possible that on so little acquaintance you

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: should like her? that but seeing you should love

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: her? and loving woo? and, wooing, she should

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: grant? and will you persever to enjoy her?

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: poverty of her, the small acquaintance, my sudden

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: wooing, nor her sudden consenting; but say with me,

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: I love Aliena; say with her that she loves me;

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: consent with both that we may enjoy each other: it

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: shall be to your good; for my father's house and all

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: the revenue that was old Sir Rowland's will I

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: estate upon you, and here live and die a shepherd.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: You have my consent. Let your wedding be to-morrow:

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: thither will I invite the duke and all's contented

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: followers. Go you and prepare Aliena; for look

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: you, here comes my Rosalind.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter ROSALIND

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: God save you, brother.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: And you, fair sister.

speaker: OLIVER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: wear thy heart in a scarf!

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: It is my arm.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of a lion.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: swoon when he showed me your handkerchief?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Ay, and greater wonders than that.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: O, I know where you are: nay, 'tis true: there was

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: never any thing so sudden but the fight of two rams

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and Caesar's thrasonical brag of 'I came, saw, and

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: overcame:' for your brother and my sister no sooner

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: met but they looked, no sooner looked but they

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: loved, no sooner loved but they sighed, no sooner

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sighed but they asked one another the reason, no

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: sooner knew the reason but they sought the remedy;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: and in these degrees have they made a pair of stairs

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: to marriage which they will climb incontinent, or

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: else be incontinent before marriage: they are in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: the very wrath of love and they will together; clubs

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: cannot part them.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: They shall be married to-morrow, and I will bid the

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: duke to the nuptial. But, O, how bitter a thing it

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: is to look into happiness through another man's

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: eyes! By so much the more shall I to-morrow be at

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: think my brother happy in having what he wishes for.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Why then, to-morrow I cannot serve your turn for Rosalind?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: I can live no longer by thinking.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Know of me then, for now I speak to some purpose,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: that I know you are a gentleman of good conceit: I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: speak not this that you should bear a good opinion

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you are;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: neither do I labour for a greater esteem than may in

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: some little measure draw a belief from you, to do

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: yourself good and not to grace me. Believe then, if

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you please, that I can do strange things: I have,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: since I was three year old, conversed with a

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: magician, most profound in his art and yet not

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: damnable. If you do love Rosalind so near the heart

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as your gesture cries it out, when your brother

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: marries Aliena, shall you marry her: I know into

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: what straits of fortune she is driven; and it is

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow human

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as she is and without any danger.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Speakest thou in sober meanings?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though I

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: say I am a magician. Therefore, put you in your

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: best array: bid your friends; for if you will be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: married to-morrow, you shall, and to Rosalind, if you will.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Enter SILVIUS and PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness,

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: To show the letter that I writ to you.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I care not if I have: it is my study

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To seem despiteful and ungentle to you:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: You are there followed by a faithful shepherd;

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Look upon him, love him; he worships you.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Good shepherd, tell this youth what 'tis to love.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It is to be all made of sighs and tears;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And so am I for Phebe.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And I for Ganymede.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And I for Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And I for no woman.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It is to be all made of faith and service;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And so am I for Phebe.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And I for Ganymede.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And I for Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And I for no woman.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: It is to be all made of fantasy,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All made of passion and all made of wishes,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All adoration, duty, and observance,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All humbleness, all patience and impatience,

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: All purity, all trial, all observance;

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: And so am I for Phebe.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: And so am I for Ganymede.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: And so am I for Rosalind.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: And so am I for no woman.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Who do you speak to, 'Why blame you me to love you?'

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: To her that is not here, nor doth not hear.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: Pray you, no more of this; 'tis like the howling

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: of Irish wolves against the moon.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will help you, if I can:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I would love you, if I could. To-morrow meet me all together.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To PHEBE

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will marry you, if ever I marry woman, and I'll be

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: married to-morrow:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To ORLANDO

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will satisfy you, if ever I satisfied man, and you

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: shall be married to-morrow:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I will content you, if what pleases you contents

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: you, and you shall be married to-morrow.

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To ORLANDO

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: As you love Rosalind, meet:

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: To SILVIUS

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: as you love Phebe, meet: and as I love no woman,

speaker: ROSALIND
text_entry: I'll meet. So fare you well: I have left you commands.

speaker: SILVIUS
text_entry: I'll not fail, if I live.

speaker: PHEBE
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: SCENE III. The forest.

speaker: ORLANDO
text_entry: Enter TOUCHSTONE and AUDREY

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: To-morrow is the joyful day, Audrey; to-morrow will

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: we be married.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: no dishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: world. Here comes two of the banished duke's pages.

speaker: AUDREY
text_entry: Enter two Pages

speaker: First Page
text_entry: Well met, honest gentleman.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: By my troth, well met. Come, sit, sit, and a song.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: We are for you: sit i' the middle.

speaker: First Page
text_entry: Shall we clap into't roundly, without hawking or

speaker: First Page
text_entry: spitting or saying we are hoarse, which are the only

speaker: First Page
text_entry: prologues to a bad voice?

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: I'faith, i'faith; and both in a tune, like two

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: gipsies on a horse.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: SONG.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: It was a lover and his lass,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: That o'er the green corn-field did pass

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In the spring time, the only pretty ring time,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding:

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: Sweet lovers love the spring.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: Between the acres of the rye,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: These pretty country folks would lie,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In spring time,  and c.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: This carol they began that hour,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: How that a life was but a flower

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In spring time,  and c.

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: And therefore take the present time,

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino;

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: For love is crowned with the prime

speaker: Second Page
text_entry: In spring time,  and c.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: matter in the ditty, yet the note was very

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: untuneable.

speaker: First Page
text_entry: You are deceived, sir: we kept time, we lost not our time.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: such a foolish song. God be wi' you; and God mend

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
text_entry: your voices! Come, Audrey.

speaker: TOUCHSTONE
